title: Synthetic Recap
body:
TORONTO — In a defensive battle where points were a precious commodity, the Toronto Raptors clawed their way to an 81-77 victory over the Vancouver Grizzlies in 1997. The game, however, will not be remembered for the final score, but for a historic and singular performance that defied the game's gritty nature.

The entire night belonged to one man: Raptors guard Damon Stoudamire.

In a game where his team only managed 81 points, Stoudamire was a one-man offensive hurricane, pouring in a staggering 42 points. He was the engine, the heart, and the sole source of firepower for Toronto, accounting for over half of his team's total output. While his teammates struggled to find their rhythm, “Mighty Mouse” was colossal, carrying the Raptors on his back against a determined Grizzlies squad.

Vancouver, led by Blue Edwards’ 18 points, fought tenaciously. They successfully muzzled the rest of the Raptors' lineup, with only Doug Christie (12 points) joining Stoudamire in double figures. Yet, every time the Grizzlies threatened to seize momentum, Stoudamire answered with another clutch basket, his scoring barrage proving insurmountable.

The final box score tells the story of two teams locked in a struggle, but it is overshadowed by one monumental line. Stoudamire’s 42-point explosion was not just a career night; it was a legendary feat, a testament to individual brilliance shining through a defensive rock fight. On this night, the Raptors didn’t just win a game—they witnessed one of the most dominant carry-job performances in the young franchise’s history.
